title: Where the Content Comes From
content:
The discussion comes from a real debate hosted on the BCAUSE platform.

Participants wrote their arguments in their own words.

No text was rewritten, summarized, or modified before being shown here.

Why this matters:You are seeing the original arguments, not AI-generated summaries.

title: How AI Groups Arguments into Themes (Clusters)
content:
The system looks at arguments that belong to the same position and groups together those that use similar ideas or wording.

Important:

  • AI does not judge whether arguments are good or correct.
  • AI does not compare arguments across different positions.
  • Grouping is based only on similarities in content.

Possible limits:

  • Two arguments about the same idea may not be grouped if they are phrased very differently.
  • Arguments that use similar wording may be grouped even if they have different intentions.

Why this matters:Clusters show recurring themes, not “truths.”

title: How AI Identifies Keywords
content:
The system looks at the text of arguments and identifies recurring or central terms.

  • Keywords are extracted only from arguments.
  • Keywords are not added manually.
  • Shared keywords create links between arguments.

Important:A keyword appearing often does not mean it is more important.
If a concept is not shown as a keyword, it does not mean it is irrelevant.

Why this matters:Keywords help reveal connections, but they do not measure importance.

title: What the System Does NOT Do
content:
The system does not:

  • Decide which argument is stronger
  • Check whether claims are true
  • Rank participants
  • Remove minority views
  • Predict consensus
  • Rewrite arguments

It organizes content to help you explore it.

Why this matters:Interpretation is still your responsibility.
